column3: the lifestyle diseases that are common in the Western world today. This is mostly because people didn't live long enough to develop them. They died of injuries -- being gored by an ox

column1: That changed when antibiotics were discovered. In 1928
column3: a drug still used today to fight bacterial infections. Suddenly
column4: infections that had been a death sentence became remedied within days. During World War II
column5: this drug treated pneumonia and sepsis
column6: and has been estimated to have saved between 12-15% of Allied Forces lives. We have been living inside the golden epoch of the miracle drugs
column8: we are coming to an end of it.

column1: People are dying of infections again because of a phenomenon called antibiotic resistance
column2: or popularly referred to as “superbugs”. Bacteria compete against each other for resources
column4: by manufacturing lethal compounds that they direct against each other. When we first made antibiotics
column5: we took those compounds into the lab and made our own versions of them
column6: and bacteria responded to our attack the way they always had.

column2: we played a game of leapfrog -- our drug and their resistance
column4: and then resistance again -- and now the game is ending. Bacteria develop resistance so quickly that pharmaceutical companies have decided making antibiotics is not in their best interest
column5: so there are infections moving across the world for which
column6: out of the more than 100 antibiotics available on the market
column7: two drugs might work with side effects

column1: It would be natural to hope that these infections are extraordinary cases
column3: in the United States and Europe
column4: 50 thousand people a year die of infections which no drugs can help. A project chartered by the British government known as the Review on Antimicrobial Resistance estimates that the worldwide toll right now is 700 thousand deaths a year. Also
column5: if we can't get this under control by 2050
column6: the worldwide toll will be 10 million deaths a year (more than the current population of New York City).

column1: The scale of antibiotic resistance seems overwhelming
column2: but if you've ever bought a fluorescent light bulb because you were concerned about climate change
column3: you already know what it feels like to take a tiny step to address an overwhelming problem. We could take those kinds of steps for antibiotic use too. We could forgo giving an antibiotic for our kids’ ear infection
column4: if we're not sure it's the right one. And we could promise each other to never again to buy chicken or shrimp or fruit raised with routine antibiotic use. If we did those things
column5: we could slow down the arrival of the post-antibiotic world.

column1:
There have been so many deaths throughout history from disease, but it seems like more people are dying of disease now because people hundreds of years ago often didn't live long enough to die of cancer or other illnesses. They were killed in factory accidents, or crushed by oxes and then dying from infection later on. This meant that fewer people got the opportunity to die of disease. In World War II and beyond, medicine has vastly improved and people are living longer than ever before. There are also about 50 thousands people who die each year who medicine couldn't help. Also, there is the problem of antibiotic resistance which bugs have adapted to. Despite this, people are still living longer and healthier lives.	0.0	2.0	Yes	4	1	2	No	No	10	7

They were killed in factory accidents or crushed by oxen or lived just enough to get injured and develop an untreated infection that ultimately kills them. Despite the field of medicine has had huge advancement since the second World War, over 50 thousand people from causes unpreventable by modern medicine. Prior to World War II, people generally did not live a long time and often died due to various diseases. After the war, advancements in medicine addressed many of those diseases, which increased lifespans significantly. Exposure to new diseases is still an issue, but modern medicine allows us to prolong life, even for diseases that have no known cures, such as HIV, AIDS, and cancer. Overall, people are living longer than the generations before them.	4.0	9.0	Yes	6	1	8			10	3
